image.altText: A woman with a bag talks to a man angrily.

props.synopsis: Around 80 passengers on the Coral Adventurer have been flown home after the cruise ship ran aground on a reef off Papua New Guinea.

title.children: Exhausted passengers arrive home after luxury cruise liner runs aground

image.altText: An aerial shot shows waves form in floodwaters as a small boat travels past trees.

props.synopsis: In wet season, Jonathan and his family have to drive, boat and drive again if they want to reach town. The remote NT traditional owner says nature has long been warning us about climate change, "but nobody's listening".

title.children: 'Nature is warning us' about climate change, but 'nobody's listening'

image.altText: A BOM satellite map

props.synopsis: Severe Tropical Cyclone Hayley has been downgraded, after bringing severe winds and heavy rain to parts of the north-west Kimberley.

title.children: Destructive winds, heavy rain as Tropical Cyclone Hayley crosses coast

image.altText: Three portrait-style photos of white men sit on top of a map of an island

props.synopsis: An ABC investigation has identified several individuals involved in a network of illegitimate corporate regulators and service firms.

title.children: How illegal gambling sites are benefiting from a network of illegitimate regulators

image.altText: An aerial shot shows a ship in dock. A caption reads: "Unloading the ship of weapons and combat vehicles".

props.synopsis: The UAE has denied shipping weapons to Yemeni separatists after Saudi-led forces said they had bombed arms at the port city of Mukalla.

title.children: 'Teetering on the brink': Fears of Middle East conflict after Saudi strikes in Yemen

image.altText: Richard Jeffares wears a polo jumper and stands in a brewery, smiling, next to a bag of gluten free grain.

props.synopsis: Brewer Richard Jeffares's Victorian company raised about $2.5 million from 993 investors in a matter of days through a method called crowd-sourced funding, also known as equity crowdfunding.

title.children: Would you invest in your favourite craft beer? Nearly 1,000 people have

image.altText: Close up of the Sports Bet app on a mobile phone in a woman's hand.

props.synopsis: Gambling giant Sportsbet pressured the Australian Communications and Media Authority into "watering down" enforcement announcement, the ABC can reveal.

title.children: Sportsbet pressured key watchdog into 'watering down' public statement

image.altText: Hundreds of people lay flowers in front of Bondi beachside pavilion.

props.synopsis: The mass shooting in Bondi and other incidents of mass violence around the world have highlighted that violence can strike anywhere. Here are some expert tips on how to escape, hide, and stay safe.

title.children: How to survive a sudden act of mass violence

image.altText: A man on a delivery bike looks at a letter with a TV camera filming him on the footpath

props.synopsis: After 401 years, the Danish postal service has ended letter deliveries as the country fully embraces the digital age.

title.children: Denmark becomes first country in world to end letter delivery

image.altText: Photo taken from a raised camera: floodwater covers a section of road.

props.synopsis: Police were called to a vehicle submerged in floodwaters near Normanton where they found the man aged in his 70s.

title.children: Man dies in floodwaters in north west Queensland

image.altText: Canadian tourists in Tokyo

props.synopsis: Ory Yoshifuji's Tokyo business employs housebound individuals to operate robots as waitstaff at a cafe and as personal tour guides in the city.

title.children: Tokyo venture allows housebound people to 'work while teleporting'

image.altText: A large hole drilled into a brick wall with items all over the ground.

props.synopsis: According to police, the robbers drilled their way into the underground vault room of the savings bank from a parking garage.

title.children: Robbers use drill to steal $52m of cash and jewellery from German bank

image.altText: People with suitcases mill about inside while looking at their phones

props.synopsis: A disruption on Tuesday prompted the rail company to request train customers postpone their journeys until another time.

title.children: Eurostar cancellations wreak havoc on winter travel, New Year's Eve celebrations

image.altText: A white yacht with black sails emblazoned with BNC sailing through water.

props.synopsis: The two-person crewed yacht on the brink of winning the prestigious overall handicap prize in the Sydney to Hobart race is the subject of a protest by a rival, which could potentially deny it victory.

title.children: Shock protest against yacht on brink of historic Sydney Hobart victory

image.altText: Russian President Vladimir Putin

props.synopsis: Vladimir Putin has towered over politics in Russia since ascending to the country's top office, initially as president for eight years, then as prime minister until that pesky thing called the constitution could be altered to allow him to run again.

title.children: The day Putin rose from obscurity to one of the world's most powerful jobs

image.altText: Footballer Sam Kerr waves to the crowd

props.synopsis: It was another big year in sport, with Ashes series, world cups, world championships and a long-awaited comeback.

title.children: Quiz: How much sport do you remember from 2025?

image.altText: Cars and caravans parked in the outback

props.synopsis: It's more than 1,000km from any capital city, but Cameron Corner, at the junction of the NSW, Queensland and South Australian borders, reckons it has one of the best New Year's Eve parties going around because it is a triple celebration over three time zones.

title.children: Where to celebrate New Year's Eve three times in one night

image.altText: helicopter hovering and emergency crews on a bush track

props.synopsis: A woman hiking on the NSW south coast has survived being bitten twice by an eastern brown snake more than 2 metres long.

title.children: 'Incredibly lucky' bushwalker survives bites from giant brown snake

image.altText: A Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777 plane takes off.

props.synopsis: Malaysia Airlines missing flight MH370, which vanished in 2014, remains one of aviation's enduring mysteries. A new search  is aiming to provide answers.

title.children: A plane vanished without trace in 2014. Now new tech is looking for MH370

image.altText: Large group of fans watch the cricket whilst signing and celebrating.

props.synopsis: The economic and social impact of the Boxing Day Test reaches far past the pitch and the repercussions of the two-day finish rippled all across Melbourne.

title.children: How the early Boxing Day Test finish spread far beyond the MCG

image.altText: A young boy with golden curly hair smiles as he sits by a table with playing sand

props.synopsis: As 2025 draws to a close and we look back at the stories that made headlines, for South Australians the year could be summarised as one where we searched for answers, with little results.

title.children: A year SA searched for answers, but came up short

image.altText: Krissy Barrett, wearing a police uniform covered in medals, stands in front of a wooden door.

props.synopsis: AFP Commissioner Krissy Barrett says there is no evidence the men were instructed to carry out the attack, which left 15 people dead.

title.children: AFP believes Bondi attack gunmen operated alone

image.altText: Xi Jinping smiles slightly.

props.synopsis: While Donald Trump was distracted, China launched its strongest-ever challenge against Taiwan. Beijing is showing it is ready for war.

title.children: China's message to international 'scoundrels' was directed at the US

image.altText: A side-on photo of Vladimir Putin holding his index finger to his lips as he sits in front of a crowd.

props.synopsis: A defence analyst tells the ABC an attack on the Russian President's state residence would be "technically" possible but would not make sense strategically for Ukraine.

title.children: Attacking Putin's home would be 'stupid' move by Ukraine, say experts

image.altText: Ingots of 99.98 per cent pure palladium are placed in a workroom.

props.synopsis: The price of palladium — used in electronics — tumbles from recent highs while the prices of other precious metals, including gold and silver, have also sharply declined in recent days.

title.children: Price of precious metal used in electronics and cars collapses

image.altText: Pictured from the back, a woman in a pink hijab on a train.

props.synopsis: There are concerns women wearing hijabs are bearing the brunt of a "horrifying" wave of Islamophobia in the wake of the Bondi Beach terrorist attack, with the Australian National Imams Council reporting a rise of hate incidents.

title.children: Women wearing hijabs targeted in anti-Muslim abuse since Bondi attack

image.altText: A black and white photo of a cricket batter playing a sweep shot with a baggy green on.

props.synopsis: A baggy green worn by Sir Donald Bradman during the 1947-48 series against India has gone to auction.

title.children: Donald Bradman's baggy green to go under the hammer

image.altText: Man with helmet and yellow jacket on e-bike with neon yellow Uber Eats bag

props.synopsis: From food delivery to sovereign citizens, Australia's laws underwent some important changes this year.

title.children: Australian laws changed in six important ways in 2025

image.altText: A bear in a cage holds its paw through the bars close to the camera

props.synopsis: South Korea is one of the few countries that allow farming to extract bile from bears, for traditional medicine or food believed to promote vitality and stamina.

title.children: South Korea's bear bile farming industry is coming to an end

image.altText: Greenacre factory collapse part

props.synopsis: More than 60 firefighters with 20 trucks were called to a factory in Greenacre just before 3pm on Tuesday.

title.children: Sydney factory destroyed as dozens of firefighters battle huge blaze

image.altText: A First Nations woman dressed in an ornate feathered headdress and outfit.

props.synopsis: Bizzi Lavelle, a Queer Wakka Wakka and Arrernte writer and burlesque dancer known in the scene as Bizzi Body, is reclaiming the hidden legacy of this art-form one tassel twirl at a time.

title.children: Meet Bizzi Body, the performer who is reviving the art of Blak burlesque

image.altText: A beach with monsoon in the treeline and water

props.synopsis: A brazen example of people smuggling has been recounted in the Northern Territory Supreme Court, after three Chinese nationals made it into Darwin Harbour on a small wooden fishing boat.

title.children: Darwin chef sentenced over role as 'Uber driver' for people smugglers

image.altText: Woman waving to hands waving back.

props.synopsis: Begum Khaleda Zia was leader of the main opposition Bangladesh Nationalist Party which was seen as the frontrunner to win the next parliamentary election in February.

title.children: First female Bangladesh prime minister dies age 80

image.altText: Josh Burns stands in a corridor at Parliament House

props.synopsis: In a broad-ranging interview for the Politics Now podcast, the rising Labor star reveals he plans to take extended leave to care for his baby daughter.

title.children: Josh Burns to take rare extended parental leave from parliament next year

image.altText: the back of a police officer watching the Adelaide Entertainment Centre tram stop

props.synopsis: Police have been given expanded powers to search people for weapons on every public bus, train and tram in the Adelaide metropolitan area ahead of New Year Eve's celebrations.

title.children: Police given extra search powers at all Adelaide public transport sites
